Dear Holly Anderton:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.

Rule 112. (1) Child caring institutions subject to 42 USC 671 shall not
permit a child caring institution staff member to begin working unless
all of the following has been completed using the forms, and in the
manner, prescribed by the department:
(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.

Investigation Complainant was interviewed via phone on 11/3/23.

interviewed at this time because it was reported Youth A is fearful

Administrator 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
11/3/23. He reported having limited awareness of the allegations

Foster Care Worker was interviewed via phone on 11/6/23.
She reported not being at the last court hearing but receiving

Normally Youth A attends court in sweatpants with her hair
3

Youth Development Specialist Procedures dated 2022. This
procedure is to ensure Youth Development Specialists understand
their role and responsibilities while working at St. John’s.
Interactions with youth are to be appropriate and respectful while
maintaining clear and appropriate boundaries. These boundaries
are outlined as follows: maintaining a separation between work
and family (not sharing their friends and family with youth) and
once staff leave the facility, staff are to continue with good
boundaries. If staff want to maintain a relationship with youth once
no longer employed at the facility, the staff are to contact the
facility and set up mentoring services in a formal fashion. Staff are
not to give youth their cell phone number. Staff are to avoid talking
about youth in front of other youth and talking negatively about a
youth’s behaviors or challenges.

Human Resources file for Staff 1 was reviewed.
Documentation indicates Staff 1 was hired on 7/31/23 and

documents in the file for Staff 1. The first took place on 9/19/23
and outlines the reasons as staff refusal to transport a youth as
directed by Staff 1’s supervisor and Staff 1 was found asleep
when he was working a 1:1 supervision with a youth. Staff 1 was
terminated, and reasons documented staff have reported
concerns of feeling harassed and uncomfortable in the work
environment with Staff 1 making comments about their body and
wanting to spend time with them as opposed to the youth. It was
reported Staff 1 was engaging in conversations with other staff
about refusing to do their job and not being paid enough. Staff 1
was observed encouraging youth to “have his back” in relation to
Staff 1 moving to a different house and liking Staff 1 over another
staff. Staff 1 was also observed to engage in negative talk about
staff and other youth with specific youth. Staff 1 was found to be in
violation of the anti-harassment and bullying policy, along with
being in violation of the supervisor policy. Documented training
records indicate Staff 1 was current on his training. He completed
“Orientation training on 8/14/23, Trauma informed care on 8/8/23,
Supervision, Attendance and YDS Procedures on 9/28/23, Sexual
harassment on 8/8/23.
Analysis Although there are no specific findings to Youth A performing oral
sex on Staff 1 or smoking marijuana, based upon interviews and
written documentation there is evidence that supports Staff 1 had
engage in inappropriate behaviors with youth and staff while
violating numerous facility policies. Several staff interviewed had
reported Staff 1 had engaged in inappropriate behaviors (play
fighting, negative comments, sleeping while supervising youth,
contact with Youth A outside of work, and sexual remarks to
female staff) when working.
Technical Assistance:
It was discussed with the facility to train staff to report
inappropriate behaviors by staff immediately to supervisors. Staff
should report to a supervisor if they witness staff behaving
inappropriately with other staff or youth.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
